Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2012 07:16PM oregongal wrote: I have been battling those pesky papillomas for 16 years.  They rarely show up on a mammogram and not always on an ultrasound.  Ductal estasia will cause some of symptoms that you have also.   Also 16 years ago, I had a ductal excision, the surgery was long, but the recovery time was rapid, I had no pain and literally went back to work in a couple of days (desk job).  They did pull out several papillomas, so since that time I have developed a lot more.  Even though I have had all these papillomas, several other lumps, ADH, multiple biopsies, partial mastectomy, reconstruction surgery, in April I had my first MRI.  They knew I had probably 6 papillomas or nodules from an ultrasound and all of them did show up on the MRI.  Since this was my first MRI, I can't tell you if they always show up or not.  I do know they have not shown up on ultrasound and mammogram in the past.  Good luck with your surgery!.
Posts.Title: Duct excision victoriah68 sunedaze-52

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2012 03:28PM oregongal wrote: I have implants over the muscle and yes, they can do a mammogram.  They literally push the implant back and take the picture.  You have to have the more experienced tech to do this, but in 12 years with my implants there has never been a problem.  The only issue I have had is my former BS would never do anything but an excisional biopsy, he didn't want to take a risk of popping the implants with a needle biopsy.  I did just have a core biopsy with ultrasound done in April, but they would only do one of the lumps (papillomas, I currently have 6) for the same reason.  I think the mammogram should be ordered by the BS, he or she would know best.  Since you are only a year out from surgery, your implants are finally settling in for good, this could be the cause of the changes to the nipple area.  I do have one side more inverted than the other.
Posts.Title: Not Diagnosed but Worried acon acon

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2012 06:59AM oregongal wrote: I have a long history of the pesky papillomas, including those with ADH.  For me this has been going on for 16 years (now 58 years old).  I have had papillomas with and without discharge, one in a complex cyst and a few other lumps thrown in for good measure.  No DCIS has ever been found, I have no family history of BC.  I have them removed in several ways, just a simple removal, a whole ductal removal, a partial mastectomy and they removed some with reconstructive surgery.  Surrounding tissue was always removed. My current situation is I have 6 of them or what we think our six.  Because of the implant, core biopsies are a little iffy, so only one has been biopsied.  One is sitting on top of the implant.  Up until this year with the development of so many, I was not given any extra monitoring, never even told I was high risk.  MY BS in 2001 predicted that I would not get cancer in the next 10 years (he was right), even with a history  of so many of them, but insisted on removal not just biopsied.  My new BS (my old one retired) wants to do a simple mastectomy, mainly because there is just not enough tissue left by the time they remove all six and surrounding tissue.  I am fighting that one but agreed to the recommendations of the tumor board.  The board decision was  1/4 said mastectomy now, 3/4 said I could wait 6 months and see if they grow.  I am sick of the whole mess, spent enough money to buy myself a couple of sweet sports cars.  Throughout the mess I have only had one MRI, as the insurance company would not cover without a family history. I highly recommend getting an MRI, it gave me such a level of comfort, there truly was nothing else but these small papillomas (smallest I have ever had).   So now the wait is on, in the mean time I am trying to come up with the $$$$ to pay for a mastectomy and reconstruction, since my insurance is not very good. I would rather get a sports car.
Posts.Title: excisional biopsy for intraductal papilloma SecretAgentL SecretAgentL

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2012 11:24AM oregongal wrote: I try and pop in on the boards when I see anything to do with papillomas.  I have been dealing with papillomas and papillomatosis, complex cysts with papillomas, some with ADH and a few other lumps thrown in to keep things from being boring for 16 years.  I have had all kinds of removals and tests.   I have no family history of breast cancer on either side.   I currently have 6 that are being monitored.  At this stage, I have not had DCIS or any form of breast cancer, remember that is 16 years!  They will remove just to be on the safe side and that should give you some peace of mind.  But like Marie5890 says your risk is slightly higher for breast cancer.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Done Yesterday Results today lisag46 lisag46

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2012 05:28PM oregongal wrote: I have been in the 6 month club a few times, it like a break up, you just have to get pass the couple weeks where it is always on your mind, which is never easy. I've even worried after a fine needle biopsy, wondering if there was cancer in the area that they didn't hit.   I have been dealing with lumps and papillomas for 16 years, lots of biospies, lots of surgeries.  Thankfully still no cancer.  I am hoping for the best for you, do what you feel is best for peace of mind!
Posts.Title: Three lumps, concerned wishfulthinking SarahsMom
Waiting for consultation..worried I'm worrying too much! hippyatheart bundleofstress

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2012 11:39PM oregongal wrote: The only other benign item that I would know of that may cause a dilated duct is duct ectasia.  I was blissfully ignorant when I was first having problems, not much out on the internet, so cancer never crossed my mind.  There might be others that have more knowledge than myself.  The clustered cysts are a mystery.  I have only had the complex cyst (cyst full of debris, mine was blood), but it too had a papilloma in it.  I don't know what kind of cancer would present itself in a dilated duct, I have had ADH and other hyperplasia but no cancer.  My BS predicted that I would not get cancer in the next 10 years, but he wanted to prove himself right and removed any lump I had.  Interesting ultrasound pictures, I never even thought of getting copies, I could print them and put them in the Christmas cards, since a biopsy of some kind is almost always an annual event.
Posts.Title: Clustered Cysts and Dilated Duct...TRANSLATION please! Thinker13 mustlovepoodles

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 10:38AM oregongal wrote: Since you list yourself as being from Vancouver, there are many other options for BS.  I would head up to the Breast Center in Seattle, I have heard very good things about it.  Another option is OHSU in Portland, they are doing a lot of research and studies.   Go back to your GP and tell them what is going on and get another BS.
Posts.Title: Hi I'm New on this forum and high risk . mesha_38yrs nwsuburbs

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2012 06:37PM oregongal wrote: I am in the same boat, all my issues in the right breast only.  My one and only MRI  (in April) was so comforting, because I always wondered how the left side was doing, I felt like I was neglecting it.  But, while it had denser tissue there were no problems.
Posts.Title: Anyone only had one side looked at and never the other? akc820608 oregongal

Posts.Content: oregongal wrote: I hope you warriors don't mind me asking a question.  I was just diagnosed at the end of October with pancreatic cancer.  Two paths confirmed a adenocarcinoma mass.  However, the Pet Scan showed nothing.  My oncologist told me that with some people cancer will not show up on a pet scan.  I find that scary, how will they find any recurrence, should I survive round one.  Has anyone had that happened to them?  My original cancer mass didn't show up on 3 previous scans, they had seen some lesions and finally did an EUS (endoscopy ultrasound), the lesions were harmless cysts but they spotted the MASS (1.4 cm).  All this time I have had MRI's on my breast since I have a history of ADH and breast papilloma's, but now I am not so sure that I don't want to go back to just having ultrasounds. 20 year history of papillomas, ADH and various other lumps so I don't get bored. Currently fighting Pancreatic Cancer Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Cancer not showing up on Pet Scan oregongal oregongal

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2012 10:45PM oregongal wrote: I had a ductogram a long, long time ago at the beginning of my breast issues journey.  I was dreading it big time, thinking it was going to hurt, but thankfully to my surprise, it was no problem at all.  I remember the physician expressed the nipple to get the bloody discharge to come out, so they knew which duct it was, then injected the dye.  I did not get results the same day, when the results came in, they showed no papilloma, so they assumed I just had an infection.  Nine months later, I was still having bloody discharge, so they did a ductal excision and pulled out several papillomas.  Since then, I have had a lot of papillomas, a complex cyst with a papilloma and lot of various lumps to keep things from getting bored.  Hoping you get some answers!
Posts.Title: Clustered Cysts and Dilated Duct...TRANSLATION please! Thinker13 mustlovepoodles

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2012 10:00PM oregongal wrote: Me too, raising my hand.  In 16 years I have only had one good mammogram, right before reconstructive surgery after having a partial mastectomy to stop the constant biopsies (mosty papillomas, plus other benign lumps).  I was so excited, I was convinced I had done the right thing with the partial mastectomy, then the plastic surgeon pulled out a few more lumps with ADH.  Now, every year, its the same circus with the usual mammogram, ultrasound and excision biopsy.  They now want to do a simple mastectomy, I just can't seem to go there plus my insurance is not that good.  I am sure the imaging center would miss me, they certainly would miss my money.  I so understand where you are coming from.
Posts.Title: Would like for just 1 time to not have to get called back clevelandgirl99 Infobabe
